title: Why endothermic KNO3 dissolution is favorable

content.question: As a sample of <math alttext="K N O 3, solid " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>KN</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is stirred into water at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the compound dissolves endothermically. Which of the following best helps to explain why the process is thermodynamically favorable at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: All endothermic processes are thermodynamically favorable.
Stirring the solution during dissolution adds the energy needed to drive an endothermic process.
Dissolving the salt decreases the enthalpy of the system.
Dissolving the salt increases the entropy of the system.

content.answer: Dissolving the salt increases the entropy of the system.
